solution.text:
Given
\(a__{p}_=ar^{_{{p-1}}_}\)
\(a__{r}_=ar^{_{{r-1}}_}\)
Dividing \(a__{r}_\) with \(a__{p}_\)
\(\frac{a__{{r}}_}{a__{p}_}=\frac{r^{_{{r-1}}_}}{r^{_{{p-1}}_}}=r^{_{{r-p}}_}\)
i.e.
\(r^{_{{r-p}}_}=\frac{_{{q*2**(r-1)}}_}{_{{q*2**(p-1)}}_}\)
Solving this we get
\(r=2\)
now using this are in \(a__{p}_\) we can find a
a= _{q}_.
Therefore
\(a__{s}_ = a\times r^_{{s-1}}_= _{{q*2**(s-1)}}_\)

content.text: In a G.P. the _{p}_\(^{th}\) term is _{{q*2**(p-1)}}_ and the _{{r}}_\(^{th}\) term is _{{q*2**(r-1)}}_. Find the _{s}_\(th\) term.
